text:
Appearance: Bright brass. Slightly Hazy. Half a finger of white bubbles. 
Nose: Citrus zest and tropical fruit. Touch Pine. Lightly sweet.
Taste: Big citrus with a decent amount of citrus bitters mid to finish. Very lightly sweet, understated. 
Body: Lively. Medium. Active carbonation
Parting thoughts: Quite a citrus IPA, but one that is well constructed. Its not an orange candy bomb.

Golden orange in color with a lasting, but thin white foam. Strong citrus aroma and flavor thats sweet orange and tangerine. Bitterness is firm leaving just a bit of sweetness in the finish. The balance on this is really nice. One well constructed DIPA.
Cloudy amber colored with a white head. Aroma of citrus, grapefruit, orange, caramel. Medium bodied, moderate bitterness, solid.
Bottle from tavour. Nice pine smell on first taste. The first sip has loads of mango and deep citrus. Really nice and balanced. Could drink this all day!

$10.99 bomber from Market Street Wine Shop, Uptown. Pours murky golden with a small, soft off-white head. Aroma of orange, pineapple, mango, grapefruit. Flavor is really bitter - wow bitter. Grapefruit peel and juice, orange rind, lemon zest, pineapple, soap, pine. Holy shit bitter.

2015 BJCP Category: 22A Double IPA
AROMA: Strong orange aroma, some alcohol. Some clean malty sweetness in the background. 10/12APPEARANCE: Flame orange hue, hazy body, visible sediment and CO2. Moderate off white froth leaves great lacing. 3/3FLAVOR: Orange flavor akin to sweet peel rather than bitter peel. Some sherbet or candy-like flavors. Bitterness is strong and dank, but not syrupy or resiny. There is a firm malty backbone, but it is not especially sweet. Alcohol is subtle. Well balanced. 17/20MOUTHFEEL: Medium-full body. Too thick to be crisp, but too carbonated to be syrupy. Alcohol warmth is minor and complements the palette. Very smooth and surprisingly quaffable (not a sipper). 5/5OVERALL IMPRESSION: An excellent overlooked DIPA. Kind of an orange bomb, but tasty, well balanced, and highly drinkable nevertheless. 9/10TOTAL SCORE: 45/50DISCLAIMER: The author is not a certified BJCP judge; therefore, this score sheet is not necessarily indicative of proper BJCP judging techniques and protocol. The author is grading to 2015 BJCP Guidelines in order to prepare for examination.

22oz bottle thanks to Steveoj. Pours out a hazy gold topped with a small head. Nose is nice pine citrus hops and a nice malt sweetness. Taste is more of the pine citrus hops a nice light bitterness on the end.
A nice break from the lighter end of the spectrum. Medium amber, slightly cloudy. Pretty mild for a DIPA. Body, aroma, taste, all right in the wheelhouse.

5/1/16. Bomber. Labeled 8.2%. Pours a murky orange w a nice sticky head. Unfiltered and throwing lots of chunks. Drinks like a 1 1/2 rather than a double but that's not bad. Body but not too slippery a mouthfeel. Forward citrus hops and a strong bitter finish. 


---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On tap at The Partisan. Nice cloudy orange body with slight head. Nose is hoppy, fruity with caramel notes. Taste is hoppy up front with citrus and pine. Bitter as well. Some really nice spices in there. Dry in the finish.

Hazy amber color; Medium body; Aroma of pine/resin hops, some floral, & fruit/citrus; Flavor of sweet malt, pine/resin hops, fruit, some caramel, and citrus; Finish is dry & bitter; Nicely balanced; Very good!

This beer is another reason why Alewerks is in my top favorite breweries. This literally smells like tropical orange juice. Like someone squeezed a handful of oranges, pineapple, papaya, mango and peaches then said "turn into a dipa now" Its so aromatic and intense. Taste is just like the aroma with a nice pop of bitterness that lingers around. There is so much flavor, and you can tell the quality of this as soon as you taste it. This one and Secret Admirer are absolute amazing tropical bombs and I highly recommend trying this beer, its worth every penny and drink it as fresh as possible so you can bask in glorious hoppiness. Cheers!
Unfiltered a plus. Light on hops. Nice beer. Nothing special but yet nothing missing from this.

Williamsburg, Va - on tap at the Alewerks Taproom. Hazy, light golden, silky snow white head, thick lacing. Juicy fruit gum, spruce in the aroma. Full-bodied flavor with some pineapple notes, a touch of citrus bitterness, trailing caramel sweetness. Decently thick mouthfeel. Saved the best for last in my visit to Alewerks.
Large Format - Cloudy orange color. No head. Lots of grapefruit flavors going on, some other fruit tastes as well. Hops flavor that is not strong and not a whole lot of bitterness.

Pours hazy orange with a white head. Head retention is ok. Aroma: hop bitterness, tropical fruit, herbal/floral notes, caramel, pine, citrus, oranges and malty sweetness. Taste: citrus, pine, hop bitterness, peppercorns, oranges/tangerines, tropical fruit, caramel, herbs, slight alcohol and spices. Dry finish with a peppery, alcohol and citrus aftertaste. Awesome DIPA that?s well balanced and flavorful. Special thanks to my friend Shea from VA for sending this brew as part of our trade.
Bottled. Orangey brown pour. Lots of head. Beautiful floral aroma. Resin. Pine and not super citrus.

Very nice. Had no idea this rated so highly when I took the first sip but it certainly deserves accolades. Golden pour with good head and lacing. Citrus and some hay. Bittersweet finish. Creamy texture and soft carbonation. Extra points for drinkability at this high alcohol level. Tap at Churchkey.

Thanks Jesse. Date on the side reads 03/25/15
This was poured into a tulip. 
The appearance was a hazy burnt glossy orange with an ample amount of ruddy brown coloring. Soft stringy carbonation rides to the top in a moderate pace. Barely any head softens to some light bubbles riding the top of the glass. A light film of lacing sticks to the sides and gently falls.
The smell had a sweet to bitter blend citrus hops with a soft crisp apple arranging itself nicely in the mix.
The taste took the bitterness and the sweet to combine. A sticky sweet citrus aftertaste starts and lingers into a wet finish. 
On the palate, this one sat about a medium on the body with a fairly decent sessionability about it. A rapid bitterness wraps itself around my tongue to pound into submission.
Overall, I say this was a really nice DIPA. I liked that initial apple aroma that blended nicely. Id say a unique DIPA that I would have again.

Bomber from Peabodys, Boone, NC. Scents of citra hops, piney, with malt. Pours medium copper with a medium white foam that lingers with good lacing. Citra hops, malt, resin, rind, good and fresh feel with a bit of thickness. Great beer! Get it when you can!

Sample, draught, during the Great American Beer Festival (Denver), savoured on October 3 2014; eye: amber, no effervescence, tiny ring of beige head, no lacing; nose: hops, pine, orange, light grain, tropical fruits; mouth: hops, pine, orange, light grain, tropical fruits, light astringency, finale in pine with light presence of grapefruit, full body, average carbonation, mildly bitter, slightly sweet, lightly harsh texture; overall: fine

FRANÇAIS

Échantillon, en fût, lors du Great American Beer Festival (Denver), savourée le 3 octobre 2014; il : ambrée, pas deffervescence, petit anneau de mousse beige, pas de dentelle; nez : houblon, pin, orange, léger grain, fruits tropicaux; bouche : houblon, pin, orange, léger grain, fruits tropicaux, légère astringence, finale en pin avec légère présence de pamplemousse, corsée, carbonatation moyenne, moyennement amère, très légèrement sucrée, texture légèrement râpeuse; en résumé : bien

UPDATED: JUN 7, 2016 Bottle from Whole Foods Fair Lakes

Aroma: bread, alcohol, spruce, 
Appearance: golden orange, 
Taste: medium sweetness, medium bitterness, 
Palate: full body, creamy, average carbonation, long finish, 
Overall: great beer

This brew pours a bright orange orange-bronze color with a medium off-white head that recedes steadily to a film. Stringy lacing on the glass. The aroma is hoppy with floral and malty notes. Medium to full body with flavors of piney hops, citrus and grainy malt. The finish is moderately bitter with a lingering fruity hops aftertaste. Solid beer all around.
Bottle thanks to Beau on RBWG bus. Pours a clear gold with small white head. Aroma is strong floral pine hop and dank. Strong hop bite, pine, resiny finish, very bitter, really enjoyed this.
Thick and viscous with a deep malty character. The star of the show is the hopped bitterness that open up quickly with grapefruit and pine and never lets up.

22 oz bottle into a Chimay goblet.

A: Pours a dark copper color. The head is a finger off-white shade with poor retention. Its disappointing how quickly the head fades; though on the positive side, it does manage to leave a bit of lacing behind.

S: Right from the start, it brings the dank, citrusy hops in a big way. Citrusy, mainly - in fact, there are some solid tropical fruit notes emanating. Theres also some cat pee, which is never a bad thing in small doses. Maybe theres a bit more malt than I really prefer from the style, but this definitely succeeds as a total package.

T: The slight malt sweetness that hits first quickly gives way to an onslaught of bitter grapefruit rind. Make no mistake, this is hella grapefruity. It becomes maltier during the finish, displaying notes of caramel, dough, toffee, and brown sugar. My problem is that there isnt much to tie together the big grapefruit with the malt backbone. Its just like cosmicevan said, this is a really sappy, syrupy kind of beer - and thats not what I want from the style.

M: Well carbonated, enough to poke through the thick body - in fact, enough to overpower the palate, even. One feature I really like: hop resins seem to accumulate on the palate, bringing more and more bitterness as more is imbibed. Im torn between giving this a great score due to the hop resin or a poor score due to the rampant overcarbonation. Meh, Ill split the difference - its a bit unpleasant feeling at first, but once the carbonation slows down, it develops a nice (if too sweet) texture.

O: Im shocked this is a 100. SHOCKED I SAY! Okay, maybe not: this is a big ol grapefruit bomb, which means if you like big ol grapefruit bombs, youre going to really like this. Me, I only like them situationally (ie. Nugget Nectar), with my preference being leaner, less sweet DIPAs. As it stands, Im still disappointed by this. Dont avoid this, just curb your expectations.

Bomber from Drake, thanks Dan! Shared with ck1 on Spit Cup weekend. Pours orangey amber with a white head. Aroma has sweet pine and citrus. Taste has sweet pine, citrus, heavy resin with light caramel. A bit of alcohol. Finishes sweetly bitter, with alcohol. Decent. But not great. 14.4

Deep very hazy golden and light copper coloured body with a nice, two centimetre tall microfoamed just off-white head. Aroma of nice crisp grapefruit and piney hops with a bit of alcohol, passionfruit, malt, caramel and sugar notes coming from the nose as well. Full-bodied; Rich malt body with a bright sweetness from fruit and a pungent but well-balanced hop bite showing pine and grapefruit predominately. Aftertaste shows some bright bitter qualities from the hops with a lot of sweetness, and a very nice mellow malty character that balances out nicely. Overall, a very nicely balanced, well flavoured and nuanced Imperial IPA with no cloying flavours nor pungency, but a solid alcohol presence, some light sweetness and a good option, not as great as I was expecting, but good, for sure. I sampled this 65 cL bottle purchased from Whole Foods in Tysons Corner (Falls Church), Virginia on 10-June-2014 for US$7,99 sampled at home in Washington on 06-December-2014.

The bottle has a faded stamp of "8 12 14" 12 AUG 2014? Just under two months old if this is the case.

Appearance: Fairly short white head that looks somewhat creamy with some larger bubbles in it. The body is a hazy orange and bronze color.

Aroma: I get a fresh cut grapefruit scent, a bit of a grassy aroma, and slightly catty. There is a bit of mango that peeps in every now and then too.

Taste: There is a rustic bread crust flavor right up front, followed by an earthy woody flavor. There is a bit of pine in the aftertaste. As the beer warms up a bit in he glass that pine character starts to dominate a lot more and becomes the primary flavor.

Palate: It has good bitterness without being overwhelming or difficult to drink. It sits in the medium body range with a good amount of malt backbone without feeling overly sweet. It does a very good job of highlighting hop bitterness but balancing (not equalizing) the malt character.

Overall: The beer was nice but it wasnt fantastic. There wasnt a whole lot of hop flavor presence in comparison to the overall bitterness of the beer. Perhaps that was the goal of the beer, given the name "Bitter Valentine." Its not a beer that will be on my radar in the future.

"A gem from Thomassova. By the name of the beer, Id think this came out a month before VDay, but it sure tastes and smells fresh. Big, dank hops...reminiscent of Maharaja, but a little lighter. Tropical fruit, pine, and orange peel with a malty backbone that only shows when the beer warms. Really nice IIPA."
Draft at Churchkey. Clear bright golden amber color, big fluffy white head with good retention and lacing. Nice aroma of mixed tropical fruit, citrus. Taste is pineapple, mango. Delicious.

Gold in color... Aroma of tropical fruit, citrus hops... Flavor is fairly dry for an east coast IPA, but well balanced with sweet caramel malts, citrus hops... Mouthfeel is crisp, solid double IPA, could have fooled me as a west coast IPA... Dry hoppy finish. Nice beer

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bomber-SA. Bright orange-gold with small white head. A: huge hops, pine and resin. Musky. T: musky pine and floral hops. Bold. Lingering bitter aftertaste as expected. Very good.

22oz bottle in a teku. Pours deep, hazy copper with a lacy, off-white head. Aroma of resinous and floral and citrusy hops, caramel and pale malts, and some dough. Flavor mainly of the hops, but enough maltiness to balance them out. Average texture. A solid beer for the style.
22 ounce bottle. Pours a clear darker gold with a decent white head. Big aroma of citrus, pine, and grass. Taste is grapefruit, grapefruit, pine, grass, and malt. Excellent.

5 20 14. 22 oz bottle into a teku. Clear dark amber body with a finger of light tan foam, tons of lacing. Nose is resinous pine, grass, and loads of citrus. Pretty typical DIPA nose but really nice. Taste is similar, sticky resin and pine with some grapefruit. Dry and bitter yet juicy and fresh hops. This is a really nice DIPA. Always wanted to try this one.

Malty hoppy delicious beer. Another super rare beer happy to try. It has a beautiful aroma

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Poured from a bottle. Clear golden color, medium frothy white head. Nice pine and oil aroma. Medium body with a hops and oil flavor with a nice finish.
Aroma of hops and fruit, caramel color with a lasting well laced white head. Great taste of fruit, and hops with an oily feel and a bitter sweet palate.

Tap. Clear rusty bright orange. Lots of nice citrus, melon, soft vanilla notes, and slight fruity juiciness. Flavor is very similar, juicy citrus, balanced, but very hop forward and lacking gross malt heaviness. Slick light to medium body. Lovely
Pours a clear orange gold, healthy white head, lots of lacing. Aroma - hops galore, citrus, grassy. Taste follows suit with lots of grapefruit, little malt sweetness.

Tap at Capital ale house Innsbruck just outside Richmond, VA
pours bright orange with a small soapy white head and sparse lacing. Nose is big grapefruit like a clean old skool double ipa with faint honeysuckle alcohol and pine. Flavors are big line grapefruit bomb all the way! Huge bitterness on tbe finish just how I like it! Perfect! Long resinous grapefruit finish. Slight alcohol burn but blends well witb the onslaught of pine and grapefruit. This is my kind of IIPA but not I can see why some dont like it.

Amazed I had managed to miss this one until now. Growler fill from the new beer shop by my house! Clear pale orange, good head. Aroma initially of beautiful pure pink grapefruit. As it warms, picks up some gummy malts and a hint of pine hops. Flavor is a masterful balance between gummy malts and grapefruit and pine hops. Yummy.

22 oz bottle. Pours a clear orange color with a small, white head that leaves sticky lacing. The aroma is grapefruit, misc. citrus, fresh hops. The flavor follows suit: citrusy DIPA with real hop intensity, nearly a note of freshly ground pepper. A touch of honey sweetness in the back. Lingering hop bitterness. Alcohol is very well-masked.

Refrigerated brown bomber dated 2/10/14, abv on bottle 8.3% poured into a snifter. Pours clear orangish-amber with small off-white head. Aroma is herbal hops, medium body, low carbonation, and some small bubble lacing. Taste is herbal hops, some malt backbone, and finishes bitter hops. Would have liked to try this fresher.

Bottle, with a date of 02/10/14, from trade with Scoonerchamps, which is funny cause hes in OK, and Alewerks is one state north of me in Virginia, but hey whatever, good aroma sweet, orange, peach, apricot, clean brownish orange color, good initiall head,faded quickly to a ring, spotty lace, bitter sweet flavor. Heavy body, thick creamy mouthfeel, bitter finish. Nice , has some real good moments. Aroma best part. Flavor tad more one dimensional good overall,
user_location: the Containment Area, North Carolina, USA

text: Bottle. Clear gold with a big white head. Aroma and taste are both dank, citrusy and grassy. Super clean and fresh. Substantial mouthfeel with carb to back it up. Absolutely excellent.
Had it on the tap. Delicious flavor of hops. A little light on aroma. Beautiful Pour with a white head that stays.
Bottles hate thanks to dextercat. Pours amber with white head. Aroma of pine and grass. Taste is smooth, sweet, hoppy, earthy, nice. Pretty easy taster, nice.

Bottle thanks to ygtbsm94 for fbw...thanks a ton! Pours a lightly hazy orange color with off white head. Very nice blend of citrusy, piney and danky aroma. Huge hop flavor with sweet, malty balance....danky, citrusy, smooth hop flavor. Moderate bitterness is well balanced. Very tasty DIPA!

22 oz bottle - pours golden orange with burnt yellow highlights. Medium bodied head with decent lacing, circular and quickly diminishing. Picking up lots of fruit with some spice on the nose. Oranges with good citrus and yeast. Full bodied with lots of bittering at the end. Malt bill nicely balances out the hops for a long pleasing finish. Really decent. Big ups to Jordan for the hook up.

UPDATED: MAR 2, 2014 On draft. Nice flame orange color. Not a lot else going on to justify that ABV. Lots of alcohol burn. I guess theres some citrus present, but its overwhelmed by the alcohol. I havent any idea how this one pulls the ratings it does. A big meh.

22 oz. bottle at RBWG, the Grand Tasting portion of the evening. Pours a clear, bright gold with almost no head. Notes of citrus fruits, florals, caramel and biscuit malts, grass, straw, honey, and earth. A hint of tropical and pine, but they didnt factor much into this one. Medium-bodied, with moderate carbonation and a resinous mouthfeel. This was a long-time want that I was thrilled to see show up, so it fell a bit short of my admittedly lofty expectations. Good DIPA, but didnt strike me as deserving of its world-class status.

On tap 4 oz. pour at Meridian Pint in Columbia Heights, Washington, DC. 

Clear, bright amber with a large off-white head and excellent lacing. Beautiful to behold. 

Aroma of citrus, intense tropical fruit ;including mango, passion fruit and guava) and caramel. 

Taste of bitter orange, grapefruit, lemon, pineapple and tropical fruit. 

Medium body and medium carbonation.

A delicious, citrusy tropical fruit salad.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Poured into a tulip glass. Inch head forms giving away to a nice lacing.Light amber colr. Aroma of orange and pine. Citrus and pine stand forth with hints of earth. Alcohol warms the palate, but does not destroy the experience. This beer is the complete package for a DIPA.

Bottle (dated 2/10/14) poured into a tulip. Pours a golden yellow color, almost amber. Half a finger of off-white head fades away into a thin ring. Aromas of dank hops, floral notes, grapefruit citrus, a bit of onion/garlic . Tasting notes of grapefruit citrus, pine, floral notes, caramel, light onion/garlic. Medium body with a semi-dry finish. Juicy mouthfeel. Definitely one of my top East Coast DIPAs.

65cl, at 8.3%Vol, as AleWerks Bitter Valentine, new exclusive American brew Anno 2012, thx alot to Mike for bringing this fresh sample over!, very complex bitter brew, fruity/bitter and slightly woody/malty, balanced, clear, rocky head, very good brew

Bottle shared at RBWG! Pours a golden orange with fluffy white head. Aroma is a hoppy bomb, lots of new world zestiness. Taste is less than the nose, but still very nice. Would love a whole bottle of this to myself.
Bottle pour avg gold. Nose big pine and resin. Hint of dank. Taste sweet up front then the aromatic hop comes through. Mid palate sweet. Pleasing bitter finish.

Bottle. Pours clear orange with a medium, frothy white head, medium retention with good lacing. Aroma is biscuit malt, earthy, pine, resin, and citrus hops with tropical fruity esters. Flavor is heavy hops and bitterness, light alcohol, supporting malt, tropical fruity esters and a dry finish. Medium body and carbonation.
22 ounce bottle thanks to ygtbsm94. Orange pour. Bitter. Tropical fruit and resin followed by big bold bitter flavor. Very nice.

22 oz. bottle shared with the group courtesy of ksurkin in May 2012. Pours a crystal clear amber color with a thin white head. The aroma and flavor had big grapefruit citrus, pine, resiny hops with a matching malt bill that had caramel and toasted bread. Solid bitterness with enough sweetness to keep it from being overbearing. Medium plus body. Got this fresh and it was well worth it.

Bottle to glass. Pours a gorgeous clear amber color with a thin off-white, almost light tan head. Fantastic aroma. A nice mix of fleshy fruit and piney hops, along with a hint of caramel malts. Flavor is potently bitter that lingers way into the finish. The fruity character of the hips is a bit more subdued in the taste than the aroma. One of the better imperial ipas Ive had in a while.
On tap at DoG, pours clear amber with low head. Aroma is citrus and pine, taste is full bodied citrus with a nice dry bitter finish
22oz bottle shared by Beau @RBWG-JAX-offwhite-gold. A-resin/pine, some med malt. T-resin/pine/some citrus rind hop bite, 2nd lt/med malt-caramel.

A: Amber/Orangish Hue, Passes Some Light, White Head Ring, Some Lacing

S: Resin, Piney, Mild Oranges

T: Resin, Piney, Oranges

M: Average Carbonation, Medium Bodied, Dry, Bitter

Overall, a really decent DIPA with a solid hoppy backbone, great drinking.
3/17/2012. From bottle. Big hoppy aromas with caramel, pine, citrus and everything needed to be up there with the best. Excellent balance and complexity. Bitter finish that just sticks around.

Bottle: Pours a brownish copper color, rather hazy, topped with a creamy khaki head. Fair retention and modest lacing. Nose is really full of hops; citrus, tropical fruits, and resin. Sweetens up as it warms with more tropical fruit noticeable at room temp. Taste is hoppy, but not overdone. I get the citrus, grapefruit, and pine all together. Not too sweet, but not too bitter. Overall a well balanced hop bomb. Thanks to ygbtsm94 for sending this my way.
This is a local favorite..hops galore and malts help this become one of my favorite DIPA!

22oz courtesy of ygbtsm94. Thanks!

A: Semi-opaque dark-orange body with a resting white foam on top. Some decent legs. Get some good head retention on this. 

N: Tons of mandarin oranges, clementines, grapefruit, and mango. A little bit of peach. Some pine and theres plenty of that sweet crystalized sugar. Very well dry hopped - very impressed.

T: Very well balanced. Plenty of bitterness mixed up with a sweet undertone. The citrus flavors shine through quite well. Perhaps not as strong or as bitter as some of the others in the style, but this fits my palate very well. 

M: Very dry, resinous, and medium bodied.

O: Definitely up there with the best DIPAs for me. Ill definitely finish this entire bottle and enjoy every sip. Every sip reveals a changing dimension.

Bottle shared on the RBWG 2013 bus. Pours clear gold with a light, white froth head. This is a hop and booze bomb with tons of sweetness, lots of rich pine, earth. Big bitterness that really stays with you. Full bodied with fine to average carbonation. Lingering resinous piney hop finish, sticky sweet sugars. Id like to try this one again at some point because it seemed pretty average to me.

This is one hell of an IPA!!! Killer nose with plenty of pine and resin.  Flavor follows with tons of pine and resin.  Loads of hops and plenty of citrus with grapefruit.  Great lighter medium body.  Well done and worth the hype!

Bomber. Amber with a slight reddish hue, slight biege head. Fairly bitter but muted resin hops, sweet malts, bit of tropical fruit. Mild+ carbonation, moderate+ body, slightly unbalanced bitterness, alcohol, becomes dry, resiny and malt finish,
Pours grin the tap a beautiful amber with thick head.  Smells floral and hoppy.  Very hoppy flavor, some malt balance.  Bit of salt and caramel.  Somewhat sticky bitter finish.
Poured from bottle. Orangish amber with minimal head. Bitter but well balanced malty aroma. Clean citrus hops, bitter on the tongue but smooth in the finish. Nice Beer.

Awesome brew. Aroma is big hops: citrus, some tropical fruits, pine. Pour is clear amber colored with a white head. Flavor is big hops, some honey, but not sweet. This is dangerously drinkable. Awesome stuff.

I guess I am the 100th rating to send this one over the top. This brew was fantastic - such separation of bitter and sweet. Lots of honey malts and bitter hops here, just very well hidden among the soft hops. Im not sure what I just typed but I know that this beer is just fucking fantastic. Thanks Jordan!!!!!!!
On draft at jakes on main in Danville VA.  Pours a fairly clear amber with an off white head.  Pine aroma.  Spruce needles and orange zest notes.  High carbonation. Bitter finish.  Nice.

22oz bomber thanks to ksurkin. Pours clear orange amber color. Some chill haze with a fingers worth of off white head. Aroma is lots of sweet tropical fruity hops. Peach, mango, and pineapple. Taste is nice sweet fruity/piney hops with notes of mango, peach, and some malt. Excellent DIPA!!
Really good double ipa.  Dank wood hops.  Smells great.  Lots of hops.  A hell of a lot of hops.  Medium bitterness.

Bomber from Grape & Gourmet. Holy hops! Clear amber pour with a slight eggshell head. Hoppy citrus hits the nose almost immediately after popping the cap. Resiny orange and tangerine aromas over a mild biscuit. Flavor is citrusy hop heaven without being brutal to the tongue. Love this!

Bottle thanks to Dean! Pours a clear gold with an orange hue and near white head that dissipates to the edges and laces slightly. Aroma has a good amount of pine with a bit of grapefruit and onion with a hint of sweet grain underlying. Flavor has a strong pine note with a bit of resin and a bit of backing onion. Slight backbone of caramel.

22oz bottle .. . has quite the hop presence .. . pours a deep gold .. medium foam .. . quite malty for a dipa, caramel, grass, sugar .. . decent bitterness .. . nice beer 

.. . .  the dog owes my buddy some money

Bottle shared by b3shine on the bus at RBWG.   Thanks Beau!  This bottle was only one month old but goddamn have I become so picky about my ipas being fresh that 1 month now seems likes 6 to me (and Bangs).   This beer tasted old to me.  Not a lot of hop character, lots of sweeter malt, cheesy hops, vanilla, butterscotch.  Was actually hard to finish the small sample.
Bottle during RBWG bus! Thanks b3shine! Nice amber pour with a good head and lacing. Really nice dank aroma with pine and citrus. Bitter hoppiness and a touch of caramel in the flavor. Delish!
Pours gold amber with a light head. Fresh hop and Citrus scents especially in orange and grapefruit. Bold citrus flavor with wet hoppy finish. Nice and crisp on the palate

Aromas of grapefruit, piney, and floral hops, and some subtle caramel.  Clear orange-amber with mostly fading, off-white head foam.  Very bitter and dry.  Light-medium bodied, average carbonation, with a clean, snappy, bitter finish.

2 ounce bottle shared by Beernadz, thanks for the share, poured an amber color with aromas of grapefruit rinds, hops, and light bitterness.  Flavors are the same less citrusy hops then expected, light toffee in the flavor as well.  Thanks again for the share.
Nice orange copper golden pour with small head.  Huge danky grapefruit rind and nice bitterness with balancing sweetness.  Great stuff.

UPDATED: FEB 12, 2017 On tap at Dog Street.  Really nice full mouth california type IPA with plenty of aroma and aromatic bitterness Copper clear but no head
Well at Fire Works a nice head and lacing. Still a great dipa.

Wales bro. Shit tastes good. Amber pour with a small off white head. Very clear. We are off to a great start. Strong mango and cantaloupe aroma. Pine, pined apple, caramel, toffee, lemon/lime zest, sour diesel, pine tar, etc. etc. This one captures a ton of different hop signatures but it all comes together without being overly disjointed. My only complaint is it is rather bitter for my tastes, but hey, its an IIPA and people like that shit. Not fucken bad.
Huge thanks to eeebigeee aka Eric. Reminds me a lot of duet. Very dank an resiny. Delicious thick sticky body. Great dipa

Bottle - many thanks to Anthony for muling this across the country for me! Pours a beautiful clear golden amber with a small white head and good lacing. Pungent, fresh aroma of grapefruit with some notes of pine - really hitting the sweet spot. Flavor is the same, lightly sweet and medium bitter with a bitter finish. Fairly light bodied and a bit oily in the mouth. ABV is masked well, almost dangerously well. All in all this is a great DIPA; one of the best I have had. Perhaps a bit too bitter (gasp!), but otherwise just about perfect.

Ok no crap!  If you can get thus beer fresh you will be blown away. This one can stand side be side with Pliny, Headytopper and the rest of the hop monsters. Color, clarity, aroma, flavor balance its all there.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle, my special pre-kickoff treat for Super Bowl XLVII.  Seductive amber color, the head is thin but relatively staying.  The aroma is pure goodness, promising some nice resiny hops.  The promise comes to fruition on the tongue.  The beer is full-up piney hops up front, and brings a ruddy malt backbone, too ... yet its light in palate and exceptionally easy to drink, especially for 9%.  Well done.  (#4939, 2/3/2013)
Bottle thanks Ken. Pours orange with decent foam head. Aroma of big citrus and earthy hops. Taste is big bitter lots of grapefruit.

The beer is clear and orange hued with a small, white head. Plenty of sticky lacing coats the pint glass. The aroma is quite nice, offering grapefruit, misc. citrus, fresh hops. The flavor follows suit. Gotta love a fresh, citrusy DIPA. A touch of honey sweetness in the back. Lingering hop bitterness. Alcohol content well disguised. Highly drinkable, it was just too easy to drink the bomber unaided. I wish I had more. This is easily the best DIPA to emerge from the DC/Maryland/Virginia area so far.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 03-10-2012

Bomber from Once Upon a Vine, Richmond. Nice to snap this one up after missing out on the trade wave. Faintly cloudy orange pour with a still lively carbonation to it. Faint caramel malts in the nose along with bright fruity hops, hints of something spicey in there. Mouthfeel is lively and brings out the flavors quite nicely. Palate not too hot, and this accentuates the piney, spicey bits. Flavors consistently good, but I wasnt overwhelmed by this brew.

Hazy orange-amber body.  Large white head.  Spotty lacing.  Nose is full of  tropical fruits, grapefruit, pine and resin.  Underlying pale malts creep in.  Incredibly flavorful bright IPA... an unexpected treat from an under the radar brewery.  Medium bodied, refreshing bitterness, dry finish.

22 oz bottle thanks to my Secret Santa, Beerman6686. Pours mostly clear orange with a tiny white head. Smells of citrus, flowers, and hints of tropical fruits. Taste is bitter, sweet oranges, and hints of tropical fruits and flowers. Medium-bodied with a smooth texture and soft mouth-carbonation, Williamsburg AleWerks Bitter Valentine finishes with some sweetness that fades to bitterness.
One of the best examples of a DIPA I have ever had. Bitter but not harsh. malt backing is great and  truly an easy drink to get down.

Pour out of 22 oz bottle, hazy orange with thin white head, aroma brought notes of some caramel and toffee, grass and pine notes with some sweet grapefruit and orange jam, some hints of earth and spice with a touch of spice.  Taste is decent but nothing special, some nice grain and caramel, into orange, grapefruit, some pine and grass notes finishing off fairly sweet with some fading bitterness. A bit underwhelming.

This poured a semi cloudy bright orange color with a beige head. Aroma was lots of tropical fruit, mainly mangos and oranges, lighter caramel malt and some lgiht alcohol notes.  Flavor was lots of fresh in your face fruityness, a little candy sweetness and a touch of booze.  Pretty damn good stuff.

bottle, roughly 2 months old.  nose and flavor both just full of resin and orange oil and fruit gelatin and wood oil.  caramel-heavy, resin-heavy pine sap and strong alcohol.  medium-thick body, high bitterness, strong spice / oil / wood resin and alcohol in the finish with lingering spice cabinet character.  definitely not worthy of top-10 double IPA placement, even affording a bit of improvement given freshness.  the hops didnt seem too faded, so I have to believe either people are getting something drastically different at the source or this just happens to be what people consider good double IPA.

Thanks to Armin for sharing - lightly hazy copper - a little oxidation in the nose, but still seems fairly fresh, with a fair amount of grapefruit, lightly sweet malt - a fair amount of fusel alcohol comes through as it warms - flavor is medium sweet - a lot of retro nasal alcohol - burns in the finish - strongly resinous hops - grapefruit - very sweet in the finish - messy.

Bottle @ Matts house, courtesy of arminjewell. Big thanks, Armin! Hazy, a bit reddish, orange appearance with an off white head. Somewhat resiny, quite rich grapefruity, tangy, herbal hoppy aroma. Somewhat toasty, rich grapefruit, lemon/orange citrusy, garlic, somewhat chewy flavor with some booze on the finish. Pretty good but not world class.

22oz bottle courtesy of RABinVA, Thanks!. this is a nice and hoppy nosed IIPA, the mouth is a little thick with a slightly sweet caramel finish, other than that its hops hops hops. nicely carbonated and well done.
22oz bottle.  Apricot aroma and taste.  Clarity could be better.  Wonderful palate that could use a little more bubbley.
transparent gold-honey, thin white head. light. Nose is caramel sugar, clay, earthy. Flavor is orange, sweet and peely, sticky sugar and mint.

Bottle.  This was the highlight of about 20 bottle a buddy and I drank this past weekend.  Pours amber with a medium off white head.  Smell is sweet orange and some mango.  Tast is more tangerine and mango with some sweetness lingering.  amber, medium yellow head. Orange peel, pine, and tangerine flavor. Mouthfeel is slick and the finish is very bitter and long.  Hell of a beer this one was.
Nice fresh citrus hop with light honey, touch of pine. Taste is loaded with citrus and resinous hops, light cotton candy. Very solid.

22oz bottle, thanks maniac.  Small off-white head atop crystal clear amber body.  Aroma is moderately sweet, pineapple, grapefruit, some melon, caramel.  Taste is moderately sweet, pineapple, grapefruit, light catty.  Medium body, some resin, light stickiness.

Huge thanks to Dmac for sharing this one. Pours out a nice, mostly clear copper color with a fading off white head. Aroma is of cat piss hops, lots of pine, citrus and sweet citrus notes. Taste is of really nice juicy hops, citrus, pine, some really nice tropical fruits, with a really nice, but flavorful punch of hops, really solid beers.

Pours a nice crystal clear dark amber with a thin head.  Hop aroma fills the room upon opening with spice, grapefruit, grass and lychee. Taste mimics the aroma with a medium body and a nice palate.  Delicious.

Snifter from bottle. A: beautiful, simcoe, slight pine, simply wonderful. App: gorgeous gold with a very slight amber hue. One finger, cream white head and nice lacing T: slight malt and sweetness, hops come through in the middle, and the finish is strong, bitter hoppyness with a coriander hint. P: full of crisp, firm bubbles from start to finish with a long lasting finish of dry, top hopping.

Bottle WPB Town Hall Meeting 2012 Clear amber ale with a small, creamy, eggshell-colored head. Good retention. The olfactory highlights are dank, grapefruity and peppery hops. Medium to full-bodied with modest carbonation. Quite bitter, but pleasant and flavorful. Lots of citrusy and biting grapefruit rind. Finishes bitter, astringent and tongue-numbingly dry. Williamsburg seldom fails to impress. Bottle courtesy of ksurkin!

Bottle. Poured clear copper color with an average frothy off-white head that mostly lasted with excellent lacing. Moderate to heavy complex citrus hop aroma. Moderate to heavy bitter flavor with a moderate to heavy bitter finish of moderate to long duration. Medium to full body with a slick texture and soft carbonation and soft alcohol bite at the finish. Very good brew.

Bottle from Capones. Poured a clear orange/amber body under a bubbly white head of average size. Aroma of juicy citrus rind, dough, lemon grass, lemon zest and grains. Fuller bodies with a syrupy mouthfeel and softer cabonation and light bitterness and some sweetness to finish off the aftertaste. Flavor of juicy wet hops, sweetness, citrus, tropical fruits, a touch of caramel and molasses, dough. This was beer of the night hands down.
pours a dark tan with nice head that ligers.@nosebis centenial and columbus. first sip is nice with lemon and citrus peal. finish is tart clear with lemon and lime

Bottle (batch #2 apparently) via a trade. Pours with a clear golden hued body with a medium sized and lasting lightly off-white head that leaves good lace. Aromas are hoppy, citrus, resin, pinesol, lightly earthy, nutty. Mostly hop character but medium caramel like and nutty/grainy malt character poke through a little bit. Clean and dry smelling. Flavors are malty, biscuity, pine, resin, citrusy, lightly grassy. Very restrained hop presence. Not too sweet, in fact its nicely dry. Could use quite a bit more of a hop punch though (and this is a very fresh bottle). Dry, medium booze, this seems to need more whirlpool and or dry hopping to make it a world beater. Still good and in the right direction.
Bottle to snifter. Looks good and smells great; nice hoppy nose. Tastes good with a nice mouthfeel. A very solid DIPA.
Tap. Caramel color with very little head. Big piney grapefruity resiny aroma. Flavor follows. Hop finish not as big and long as some but still pretty bitter and dry.

Bottle shared by sloth. Bright orange in color, nice little head. Good nose... tropical fruits, some pine notes. Taste is a very well balanced DIPA... Light tropical fruits, grapefruit, citrus, some piney. Dry with a nice malt presence. Alcohol was well hidden, I didnt know it was 9 percent unitl saw the content here. Body is light and very sessionable. Overall: Nice DIPA, thanks bert!

April 2012 release, 22oz bottle thanks to ksurkin: Pours a clear deep golden brass with a clingy-lacing froth of off-white head.  Has a fresh resinous hoppy nose with a lightly sweet malty backbone.  Starts with good fullness and fine carbonation with ample sweetness and loads of juicy piney hops before a slightly drier bittersweet finish.  Great hop profile, yet well-balanced.

Medium statured off white head with good retention and lace. Clear, copper/orange color. Nose jumps right out at you with citrus and light pine, hint of tropical fruits and some dankyness. Body id medium, lil oily sticky on the palate, soft carbonation. Fairly dry malts hangin behind some sweet and resiny hops, fruity, grapefruit, leafy and faintly perfumy. A tad bit resiny also. Nice juicy bitter finish. A fair quaffer. Better than expectyed. Props to Bim for the bomber!

22 oz. bottle, pours a mostly clear golden copper with a small off-white head. Nose bursts of tropical fruit, with passion fruit, pineapple and mango, citrus hops, bitter orange and grapefruit peel, and sweet caramel malt. Flavour also bursts of the same tropical fruits, but amplified with truckloads of hops -- begins with mango, pineapple and passion fruit, resinous and citrus hops, and a nice caramel malt backing. Extremely full-bodied with the tropical fruits and citrus hops scorching the palate to perfection. Masterpiece of a IIPA.

22oz bottle pours a bright orange with a creamy, white head.  Nose is musty, pine, grapefruit, flowers, honey, earthy, onion patch.  Flavor is sweet, bitter, heavy orange, light honey, spicy, pine needles, grapefruit.  Full bodied, bitter, refreshing finish.

Bottle split with pat and vin. Pours a light hazy orange amber with frothy white head. Aroma is fresh grapefruit and light hop. Mouthfeel is light and refreshing, a bit muted but some fresh citrus fruits.

Clear golden with amber hue big white head that fades leisurely leaving excellent lacing... Piney fruity dry very hoppy aroma stone fruits, fairly spicy... Flavor profile matches the aroma intensely, more pine that stonefruits... Lively medium body dry finish...

650ml bottle. 

It pours a clear amber with a foamy white head.

Luckily though it is decently old (for an IPA) the smell is still there. It is definitely hinting more malty though. There is some sweet tropical notes and some citrus rind. The malt is sweet smelling with some bread and caramel.

The flavor is nice. Good hop flavors with a biting bitterness, it has no shortness of that. But I think the hops could be a bit better, more of a slap of citrus. This one is more of a pine one which I like, but it isnt really complex. The malt isnt as prevalent in the flavor but leaves a bit of a balancing sweetness.

I have some chili johns cooking, this is going to be a perfect pair.

Bottle at Brads tasting at with friends at home. Pours a honey vopper, medium to high carbonation with awesome lacing web patterns. Head was on the smaller side, maybe a half a finger. Aromas of cheesy hops,  nelson, pineapple, resin funk. Taste is bitter and tropical hop oils with endless floral, and fruity hop undertones. Finishes nice and bitter on the tongue. Refreshing and amazing IPA. In my top 3 of the last year next to heady topper, and lagunitas sucks holiday. Find this, Try this. Tasty man.

Draught at Whole Foods Devon:  Aroma of hops, hop oil, resin, citrus, tropical fruit, grapefruit, and mango.  Poured amber in color with a small, creamy, dense, off-white head that lasted throughout.  Very slightly hazy.  Not sparkling at all.  Flavor is medium bitter and heavily sweet.  Tastes of malt, hops, pine, resin, citrus, grapefruit, hop oil, and grass.  Medium body.  Oily, then dry texture.  Average carbonation.  Malt, hop, pine, resin, hop oil finish is heavily bitter and dry.  9%ABV is completely hidden throughout.

Bomber shared by James on his 30th bday.  Holds shit this is good.  Clear pale golden Orange pour with ring of offwhite head.  Some sticky head.  Delicious green and resinous and bitter.  Hits all the right notes, without going across the line of being unbalanced.  No indication of 9% abv. Lingering bitter finish is very pleasant. This is definitely one of the better dipas Ive ever had.

UPDATED: FEB 10, 2013 Updated rating now that Ive tasted 3 different batches over the last year or so. Seems to have really hit the mark with this latest (Feb. 2013) batch.
------- one really took me by surprise. Perfectly balanced, beautiful citrusy aroma with the perfect amount of bite. Pours a lighter than most DIPAs but packs just as much punch.

UPDATED: MAR 19, 2012 Thanks to ksurkin for this gem. Pours such a deep and remarkable copper-gold color. Fragrant and rich hops explode from the glad, citrus, resin, grassy. Flavor is amazing. Such complexity and hop flavor without any excess bitterness. Oh hell yes.

Bottle from watson1977 (THANKS!!). Pours clear amber with a nice soapy white head that fades to a wispy film and sudsy collar. Aroma is bright and clean orange peel and piny citrus hops. Taste is so smooth and clean with a great citrus piny bitter hops and gentle caramel that balances everything very nicely. Palate is medium and smooth with a dry chalky finish. This is one of the best Double IPAs I have had.

Bottle shared by portableparty!  Clear dark orange pour, soapy carbonation and an aroma of fresh oranges and a little hops.  Flavor is clean soapy orange hops, very light malt to balance it out and finished fruity and dry with a hint of bitters.  God damn, fucking awesome.

Bottle from ksurkin, thanks Ken!!  Aroma has huge notes of fresh citrus, tropical fruits, flowers, caramel, toasted malts and some light herbs.  Great hop monster!  Medium/dark amber orange hue with an average off-white head that left good lace.  Flavor is very heavy bitter and heavy sweet.  Palate is full bodied and watery soft/average.  Overall a wonderful IIPA.  The best Ive had in quite some time!  Fantastic brew on every level!

From notes. 

The beer itself is a transparent light caramel color with a bubbly off-white head that fades away as the glass progresses.  

There is a fair amount of bready sweetness in the nose to go along with a mainly grapefruit and pine hop bitterness.  There is some other tropical fruit as well.

This a well constructed East Coast DIPA, which I enjoyed, despite my preference moving away from that style toward the West Coast hop bombs.  There is a noticeable sweetness up front that I would guess is mostly pale malt with a bit of caramel malts blended in.  Citrus hops carry most of the flavor, with grapefruit bitterness being the strongest.  Spicy pine adds a kick toward the end.  Some pineapple and mango add a little bit more of a tropical fruit kick in the background.

For a DIPA, this has a fuller body and medium carbonation.  It is smooth and pleasant, with a smooth filtered feel.

UPDATED: MAR 29, 2012 Copper color, good lacy. Very earthy flavor, oniony.  Good citrus flavor and mouthfeel. Originally, 4.2

Bomber, shared with and courtesy of Pat.  Pours copper, small head, with decent lacing. Aroma of sweaty Armenian taint...pure onion.  Sweet malt flavor quickly fades as the bitter hops take over.  All earthy oniony, slightly floral, earthy hop flavor.  Top notch IPA

Bottle. Pour is deeper gold with a white head, good retention/some lace. Aroma of big citrus, floral hops, caramel malt. Taste is bitter citrus: tangerine, pineapple, resin, caramel/toffee malt, light booze. Palate is soft, oily, long bitter finish. Very good.

Picked this up in a trade. Very stoked to try this very highly sought after beer. 

A - Beautiful copper  and gold colored beer. Excellent clarity and really gorgeous. Half a finger of head was produced on a moderate pour. Nothing too impressive in that regards. The beer has solid lacing on the glass each swirl.

S - Nice big hop profile. Lots of pine, hop resin, citrus fruits like lemon and tangerine. Very fruity and very hoppy. Im getting a solid degree of dry hops as well. Smells exactly as a DIPA should.

T - Whoa. Gigantic hop explosion, lots of bitterness and very mind blowing. Im getting loads of hops on the front and back of the tongue. Theres a nice malty taste at the back of my tongue, lots of citrus on the front. 

M - 90% carbonation on a mouth swish which opens up more of the citrus profile. Lingering hop resin is a bit hard to deal with though.

O - Its like an amped up Hopslam or perhaps a bigger version of Heady Topper. It lacks the smoothness of Pliny or the drinkability of Daisy Cutter. Its somewhere in the middle but wicked impressive.

22 oz bottle.  Clear copper brass with a webby white head.  Nose is cat, caramel, orange, grapefruit and musk.  Slick, oily, bitter yet cloying with a lingering buzz.  Taste is onion grass, toffee, grapefruit peel and earth.  Finishes dank with herbal spice and Old Spice.  Quite hoppy but too feral, coarse and gritty for my taste.

22oz bottle. Poured a golden color with a smaller sized head. Aromas of citrus, some fruitiness and some floral hopiness. Some resin. Tastes of citrus, some grassiness, toasted caramel, and fruity. Lighter alcohol in the finish, but overall well hidden.

Bottle. 22 oz. Split with and courtesy of Tom. Pours a radiant orange with a thin white head. Plenty of shostring lacing. Aroma of fresh, crushed-up pineapple with some juicy hop, mago, and pine resin mixed in; this guy is a serious sniffer. Big, bold, delicous pineapple flavor with some very juciy, slightly bitter-sour clementine citrus in the finsh. Smooth, light, crisply-carbonated body with a bitter-sweet palate. This IPA is goddamn delicious, oily, and fresh-tasting. Try it man. Tasty.

Sweet mango, tangerine, and orange peel aroma. I had a small sample of this shortly after its release. From a 22oz. sample I now smell those same aromas, but now with a touch of cat urine, which isnt necessarily a detractor. Shimmering amber, medium yellow head. Orange peel, pine, and tangerine flavor. Alcohol well masked. Delicious, varied, and a good level of bitterness, but a bit resinous. Extremely well hopped in both quantity and quality.

(1pt,6oz bottle) Poors a clear reddish-orange amber with a small to medium off-white head. Aroma is very citrus-hoppy--a lot of orange, grapefruit, and some lemon. Aroma is sweet, too; hints of grass, pepper, and pineapple. Medium to full bodied, moderately carbonated. Very bitter flavor, lots of citrus (again: grapefruit, lemon, some orange), and pepper. Fairly astringent mouthfeel. Sweetness is mild and only present for an instant up front before the bitterness takes over; and a hint of sweetness peaks its head in the finish before long bitter aftertaste. Alcohol comes through just a little. Its good, a little ones-sided on the citrus-hops, but it does that part well. Edit: It improved as I drank it.

Bottle shared by Dallas.  Aroma: dank, resin, pine sap, grapefruit, touch of malt.  Pours clear golden with a thin white head.  Flavor: grapefruit, pine, firm bitterness but not overly aggressive, just a hint of malt, basically a vessel for hops.  Medium body and carbonation, nice brew.

Pours a light golden amber with a thick white head. Big tropical and citrus fruit nose, tiniest bit of caramel malt in there as well. Taste is sweet, but more bitter than the aroma suggests. Very drinkable for the ABV, light to medium body with a nice amount of carbonation. Awesome local beer

Bottle shared by Dallas, thanks man 
Appearance: Clear golden with a small off-white head  and good lacing 
Aroma: Tropical fruit and citrus 
Taste: Fruity, grapefruit and grassy  
Wow, very nice and well balanced

Fresh bomber.  The pour yields a mostly clear, dark orange-amber body with a small but dense cap of dusky beige froth.  Quickly collapsing to a bubbly outer edge with a thin center patch, the head yields sticky, tattered bands of lacing.  Immediately, the nose reveals what seems to be my newfound arch nemesis, Simcoe hops.  Their signature savory, meaty, catty aromas are off-putting.  Secondary notes of grapefruit are buried too far beneath to make a positive impact.  Hefty malts are driven by buttery toffee mostly.  While the flavor of Simcoe never seems to match the intensity of the generally unpleasant aroma, I do still get some meaty characteristics that I dont think should be present in a beer.  Grapefruit pushes forward a bit, bringing along its bitter pith and fruity rind, but again, it falls short.  Toffee again comprises the malt base, albeit fairly well attenuated and not overly sweet.  The palate is robust, yet relatively dry, with average carbonation and a warm, alcoholic, somewhat papery finish.  Overall, Id call this a cleaner, better-attenuated version of GUBNA, a beer I detest.  Not much of anything for me to come back for on this one.

Bottle thanks to Dallas. Pours a copper color with a medium white head. The aroma is sweet resin and rich fruit. The flavor is damn good; rich resin and bitterness, very large, drinkable, light tropical fruit and a bit of candy. Very nice. Competes with the better IIPAs.

Serving: Draft at Fireworks in Leesburg.  It pours a nice copper color with an almost creamy  off white head.  The nose is big, resinous, dank hops.  The flavor is pretty much all hops with lots of sticky, dank notes, a little tutti fruity gum, and some tropicals.  Medium bodied and dangerously sessionable.  Great lasting bitterness.  This one lives up to the hype.

Clear copper pour little hue of red to it, thin white head little lively bubbly carbonation .... aroma of citrusy hops, chewy caramel malts, mango, rindy ..... taste is hoppy and bitter, floral/piney, rindy, citrusy (grapefruit, mango) and oddly light strawberry, apricot and chewy caramel malts ... mouthfeel is oily and resiny .... finish is dry hoppy and resiny with a lingering bitter bite stuffs awesome reminds me of sculpin/pliny .... abv hidden well .... hop heads dream

22 ounce bottle. An amazing nose, lots of hops: citrus, floral, and grassy. The flavor is great, huge hop profile, the malt notes balance this beer very well. Man the nose on this is brilliant. Great beer.

Pours a clear golden amber color with a thick, fluffy white head. It has just the right amount of carbonation and the head laces the glass like the rings inside of a tree trunk. Aroma of juicy pineapple chunks, freshly-squeezed grapefruit juice, and perfectly ripened mangoes. moderately sweet tropical fruit flavor from the mountains of hops packed into this beer. It becomes progressively more bitter and finishes long and dry. Light-medium body that goes down smooth

Bomber from Vintage Cellar. Pours a clear amber color with a thin off-white head. Decent head retention. Aroma of floral, herbal, tropical and citrus hops, strawberry and mango, caramel malts. The taste is tropical, citrus and resin hops, strawberries, lemongrass, caramel malts. Medium-full bodied, average carbonation and a moderate lingering bitterness. Nice.

Bomber from PUBN.   Pours clear dark straw with 3-finger off-white head that laces well.  Nose is humongous pineapple, mango,strawberry, tangerine, and resiny hops.  Tastes rich, very hoppy, not bitter but extremely fruit, with the big pineapple, honeydew, and tangerine flavors, a smooth and hoppy mid-palate, and a crisp and floral peppery finish.  This one is a true hop lovers wet dream.  Gets a bit hot late, and perhaps a tad malt light, but is absolutely delicious.  This one reminds me a lot of Pliny the Elder and Sculpin.

22 oz bomber    This is a wonderfil Double IPA.  The ale poured a clear gold with white head that dissapated with no lacing.  The aroma of citrus and grapefruit jump out of the glass.   Your mouth fills with pine and evergreen.  The alcohol is deceptive and balanced.  The carbonation is lively and adds to the flavors coming at you.  This is one to sit back and enjoy.

fairly clear orange amber body with a large rocky off-white head. Big citrus and resiny hop aroma on a pale malt background. Sweet pale malt, big citrus hops and a resiny background. Medium body with moderately high carbonation

22oz bottle.  Pours amber with a medium off-white head.  Great hop aroma of pine, citrus and tropical fruits with a touch of caramel.  Great hop flavor with pine, citrus, peach, tropical fruits and a hint of caramel.  Very balanced with a great but not overly bitter finish.

22oz - Crisp hoppy pine and spruce round with a touch of floral grapefruit zest.  Pillow soft nutty earth malts let the hops shine bright.  Medium bodied, dry finish.  Best beer ever purchased from Williamsburg.  Should be considered for year round.  Great job...

On tap at Rustico in Alexandria. Served in a goblet.

Alcohol is listed as 9.0%.

A: Pours a clear light copper color with a nice tall off-white head with loads of lacing and great retention. I think I got those colors right; its always so damn dark in this place.

S: My initial impression is loads of tropical fruits with a bit of citrus rind in the background. There may be a bit of malt, but Im not getting any here. Mango and papaya abound. A bit of tangerine in there as well.

T: The flavor does not let me down either. Great continuation from the nose with prominent tropical and citrus fruits giving way to a fairly-heavy bitterness. Just a touch of warming alcohol. Load of fruity hope smack my tongue around.

M: Light-medium body with crisp carbonation. The feel is dominated by a fantastic bouquet of hops. Dry an bitter through and through.

O: A very, very solid offering. This is something that I am extremely proud to say came from Virginia. Now, please make more as I didnt hear about this beer until all the bottles were already gone.

UPDATED: AUG 12, 2014 Draft at Rustico. Poured a clear orange/amber color color, virtually no head beyond a tiny wispy white head. Aroma was grapefruit, tropical fruit notes, pine resin. Flavor was incredibly hoppy, pine and resin, grapefruit. Enjoyed this quite a bit.Ive had this numerous times. Im going to bump up the rating a bit more. Very good fresh. Wonderful.

On tap at Whole Foods.  Appearance: clear golden orange color, soapy yellowish white head. Aroma: floral citrus grapefruit, some pine. Taste: sweet floral citrus up front and throughout with that bitter hoppy pine joining in halfway through the end, balanced floral pine aftertaste. Mouthfeel: medium to thinner body. Overall: this is freaking delicious!!!  Ive always been a fan of their Drake Tail IPA and this blows me away. Well, well done!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: MAR 3, 2012 651mL thanks to ksurkin. Pours clear, darker orange with a larger, yellow head. Soapier rather than rocky retention. Nice lace. Nose at first is fresh tropical fruits, slightly muted with too much soapy character. Decanting allows sweet honey and cantaloupe to emerge with vanilla and booze. Taste is nutty bitter, thicker, slightly slick with fatty macadamia nut. Quite the long, bitter finish. Palate is bit astringent, a bit butterscotch slick. 9% is well hidden. 2/24/2012 7/4/7/3/14=3.5651mL from the Foodery in Philly. Awesome, rocky buttermilk to yellow head with nice retention and sticky lacing. Nose is fresh tropical melon, meaty jackfruit and sweet cantaloupe. Fresh, tropical hop nose. Taste is more quenching, more elusive quenching butterscotch. Nutty astringency is gone. Finish is neutral at first, about to be a superlative DIPA but gets slightly piney and tree bark bitter/aggressive over time in a long finish. But overall, much improved over my first bottle.
Our first bottle half froze trying to quickly chill it down for a tasting. Maybe thats why it became overly bitter and nutty, but Ive had beers freeze before that turned out perfectly fine. Maybe these ironically fragile DIPAs cant handle such freezing. Whoops. 3/2/2012 8/4/7/5/15=3.9

Crystal clear orange/copper pour with a magnanimous frothy white head. Nose isnt overly aromatic, but holds beautiful notes of fresh cheesy hops, tangerine, cedar and tamarack evergreen presence, grapefruit flesh, sage, pot, steaming bark mulch, and even touches of lighter floral components on the edges. Really interesting nose because it isnt nearly as big and vibrant as other IPAs, but good lord is it complex and balanced. Flavor brings more big earthy and evergreen hops with less citrus. Loam and spruce abound with some really good lemongrass bitterness about 4/5 of the way through the flavor. Im a bit torn on the mouthfeel because i love a good aggressive hop character with that lingering bitterness, but at the same time the fact that theyve rendered a 9% beer to taste like a sessionable 4% option is an otherworldly achievement. Really really good, and really cool because its just different from almost any other double IPA out there.

Thanks craftycarl21! Orange amber pour with a massive rocky white head that lingers nicely. Big dank fresh cheesy hops, orange peel flesh, and hints of evergreen in the nose. Very fresh and wet with summit like saltiness. The flavor holds hints of caramel malt with fresh hop dankness and orange peel, with sweet grapefruit juice notes and a bit of herbal evergreen. Very light and poundable, which is phenomenal  given the abv. A great effort.

Pours a clear golden amber with a thick tan head...pretty decent retention.  Aroma has nice stonefruits and citrus...peach, mango, pineapple...with just a hint spice and very faint biscuity notes.  Flavor is loaded with floral citrus and stonefruit!...[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ balance of sweet/floral and spicy...just a hint of piney notes.  Very, very tasty with a nice amount of bitterness.  Mouthfeel is medium and silky with a nice sticky hoppy finish that lingers with grapefruit.    Great beer!
WOW!  This is one fantastic IPA!   Aromas are veritable herbal fruit salad.  Tropical citrus fruit flavors waft across the palate finishing with a little bitterness.  Overall a fantastic double IPA.

22 oz bomber.  Pours a clear light copper color with a medium sized frosty fluffy white head.  Aroma of sweet grapefruit, fresh semi bitter hops, mango notes, pine and hints of floral tones.  Taste of lightly sweetened grapefruit, mango, fresh hops and pine.  Nicely balanced.

22oz from Grape and Gourmet.  Poured a crystal clear amber orange color.  Initial nose is pineapple, mango, and grapefruit.  Lightly carbonated and little head retention.  The further through it the more piney and resinous it becomes.  The beer is delicious.  Incredibly smooth for such a huge IPA.  I feel it could be slightly more carbonated.  It sticks with ya for a second and mellows right out.  A fantastic IPA that deserves to sit on the top shelf of IPAs.  Proud to say this is brewed just down the street from me.

Bottle from Grape and Gourmet. Bitter Valentine pours orangish color.  Very little head, if any at all is poured.  Nice clear pour. Little bit of lacing.  Decent carbonation as bubbles shoot to the top of the glass.

Now on a lot of big IPAs I like to let the bottle sit there and see if the aroma of hops pour out of the bottle.  A lot of really huge IPAs do this but with Bitter Valentine I really didnt get that.  So I picked up my glass and took a huge whiff and was greeted by a really nice tropical fruit aroma.  Citrus, grapefruit, apricot, mango, peach with a small bit of pine and a very little malt backbone.  This is mainly just a fruity aroma.  While very very nice for some reason I wanted more.  But dont get me wrong here, its fantastic.  Straight up West Coast style with some East Coast thrown in.

The fruitiness in the aroma hits first with the taste. Just a barrage of tropical fruit.  Good stuff.  Then mid palette the fruitiness cuts off and bitterness comes in.  Its a lovely taste and got better and better as I drank.  The taste matches the greatness of the aroma and you definitely cant say that about every beer.  This beer rings in at 9% like I said but it doesnt really show up at all.  Maybe a little bit of a burn on the aftertaste.

The mouthfeel is medium bodied.  Coats the mouth and goes down nice.

Bottle. Orange-amber sunset colored pour with a medium, frothy white head. Aroma is wet hops, citrus oils, pine, grapefruit, sweet malt and a ouch of caramel. Wet, fresh, luscious hops are the bulk of the taste of Bitter Valentine along with pine needles, grapefruit, citrus oils, sweet malt and chewy caramel. Theres also soft pineapple, faint peach and hints of tropical fruit.  Not overly bitter and perfectly balanced, flavor-wise. Body is slightly resinous with a soft, dense, creamy carbonation. Medium-full overall with a pleasant lingering bitterness. Finishes with more wet hops, pine, chewy caramel, sweet malt notes, grapefruit and peach. Very nice beer! Another home run for Geoff and Alewerks!

22 oz. bottle from Grape & Gourmet (bottled February 14, 2012).  Expected rusty orange pour with a thin off-white head.  Aroma of grapefruit and pine needles.  Everything I would expect from the aroma; bitter piney hops, juicy grapefruit, and hints of pineapple.  While bitter, this is addictively drinkable.  Pliny The Elder, Sculpin, Double Jack, you now have company.

UPDATED: MAR 5, 2012 22oz bottle FRESH from grape & gourmet. so weve all been waiting patiently for our buddy Geoff at AleWerks to crank out a double ipa and hes finally done it. super stoked for this brew so ive poured it into my AleWerks snifter and here we go with the first rating!

pours a beautiful, crystal clear, peach-gold capped by a rich, bright white, sudsy head that leaves sticky rings of lace with great legs. aroma is absolutely fantastic, amazingly crisp and clean, with fresh, juicy citrus notes of pink grapefruit, tangerine, and orange peel backed by notes of sweet apricots, peach nectar, and floral esters with subtle notes of dry grass and spicy pine esters emerging as it warms. flavor is magnifiscent as well with a huge blast of sweet apricots, tangerines, pineapples, and peach skins up front that mellow into grapefruit citrus, white grapes, and kiwi with mellow, toasted, crackery malts emerging just ahead of wonderfully unique, perfectly spiced, piney finish. palate is medium bodied with perfect carbonation and a masterful balance of tropical sweetness, pine spice, and grassy, herbal hop bitterness. overall, i may be an AleWerks homer but there is absolutely no doubt in my mind that this is a world class double ipa that rivals the best ive had from either coast. bravo, geoff.
